moves.3... Nc6 4. d4 cxd4 5. Nxd4 Nxd4: I don't think this is good, because it brings my queen into the centre
moves.6. Qxd4 b6: the b6, e6, Bc5 plan is a bit slow
moves.7. Bc4 e6 8. Bg5 Bc5 9. Qd2 h6 10. Bh4: Bxf6 and O-O-O might have been better, but I didn't want to give up the bishop pair
moves.10... g5 11. Bg3 Bb7 12. f3 d5 13. exd5: This sacrifice is probably bad - and maybe Be2 and O-O-O is better - but I think it's about the only way to get an advantage. And it looked interesting!
moves.14... dxc4: Refusing the peice just loses a pawn
moves.15. Rhe1+ Be7: Forced, because Kf8 loses a rook.
moves.18... O-O 19. Rxe7 Re8: ... but there was no need to lose this one
moves.20... Qf6 21. Ne4: Attacking the queen and defending the bishop, so Rad8 is nothing to fear
moves.21... Qe6 22. Qc3: Noticing the knight fork on f6
moves.22... Kh7: Rad8 may be better, because then black has the defence 22. Nf6+? Qxf6! 23.Qxf6 Re1#
moves.23. Qf6 Qxf6: Kg8 may be better, to defend f7.
moves.24. Nxf6+ Kg6 25. Nxe8 Rxe8 26. Kd2: A blunder, losing the bishop to the pin on Rd8. There is nothing wrong with Re7, or c3 to activate the king without losing material. Fortunately I was able to win the endgame without the extra piece.
moves.26... Rd8 27. Rxa7: Kc3 might be better practically, although if black takes the bishop it makes no difference. I just took the pawn and hoped for the best!
Not wanting to give black a passed pawn!
moves.33... Rxc3+ 34. Kb4 Rc2 35. a4: Ignoring the threat to my kingside pawns, to push my passed pawn
moves.35... Rxg2 36. a5 Rxh2 37. a6 Rb2+ 38. K: the f pawn is unimportant. Black should probably sacrifice the rook (while he can), and hope his pawns beat my rook
moves.40. a7 h5: Rxa7 ?! is still probably the best chance - it may even win
moves.41. Ra5 Rb3+ 42. Ka6: Now the pawn promotes, and I win
moves.42... h4 43. a8=Q h3 44. f4: Opening the diagonal to h1, and setting up a rook check on g5
